Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: A Fully-Digital Transceiver Design for mmWave Communications
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is to provide a new way for developers of wireless systems to test their prototypes. The estimated market size is $300 M and supports the development of many new sectors, such as next-generation cellular systems, self-driving cars, robotics, augmented/virtual reality, and unmanned aerial vehicles (drones). This project will advance a new technology, affordable and technically advanced software-defined radios (SDRs), for testing. <br/><br/>This SBIR Phase II project will advance the translation of SDRs. The millimeter wave (mmWave) frequencies from 30-300 GHz can be used to meet increased demand, but getting systems to work in the real-world in these frequencies remains challenging. This SBIR Phase II effort will advance an SDR to prototype systems across all layers of the protocol stack.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wireless research is plagued by an over-reliance on theory/simulations, while experimentation remains very rare. The main reasons are that experimental wireless  hardware platforms are expensive, and reference software implementations are hard to come by.

Pi-Radio's vision is to democratize experimental research through affordable software-defined radios (SDRs) that feature bleeding-edge transceiver techologies, combined with a suite of free and open-source software implementations.

In this NSF SBIR performance period, Pi-Radio has designed several SDRs:

- Pi-Radio "CV Raman": 8-channel multi-analog beamforming

- Pi-Radio "Hedy Lamarr": 8-channel fully-digital beamforming

- Pi-Radio "JC Bose": 4x64 split-hybrid beamforming

Pi-Radio is also working on an 8-channel SDR that operates in the 6-24 GHz band, and also on a joint effort with UCSB to build 140 GHz SDRs (the 140 GHz SDR effort is DARPA funded).

On the software side, Pi-Radio has built a channel sounder, data link implementation, and a simple wideband RADAR system. These are available on GitHub.

Through this journey, Pi-Radio has faced many challenges including: a) semiconductor shortages; b) manufacturing (fabrication and assembly) challenges; c) severe inflationary effects; and d) market challenges with low volumes and low margins. On the technical side, Pi-Radio has learned best practices to de-risk against these challenges. On the business side, Pi-Radio plans to diversify its target market into the defense ecosystem as well.

Software-defined radios are a critical requirement in enabling experimental wireless research; Pi-Radio's goal is to play a role in making this a reality.
